metadata.name: ùêÉùêûùêöùê´ùê≠ùê° #174
metadata.description:
Witness hundreds of small geometric objects gather under one roof to create a cosmic rain!

Ever since I was a child, I have always been good with geometric objects. I used to draw objects such as cubes, cylinders and prisms on paper for hours. As if I'm getting lost in every line between those geometric objects! In this way, every detail of geometry in my daily life and in my other existing life attracts my attention.

Recently, I have been doing research on colors and color palettes, it is really impressive how thousands of color mixtures affect each other and the psychology of living things!

‚àΩ‚àΩdepending on the screen size you can get different resolutions, which brings out a different side of the project! so you can run this project on all screen sizes and get the output!‚àΩ‚àΩ

Key:
- Press "s" to export an PNG image


Made with p5.js

metadata.name: Kinetograms #129
metadata.description:
Each Kinetogram traces the movement of a number of simple shapes constrained within a single cell or a grid of cells. Forces are applied to the shapes in the form of attraction, gravity or shaking.

Some Kinetograms are partially or completely reflected, vertically or horizontally, some with chromatic replacement.

The aspect ratio is 3:4. The palettes are predominantly based on found textile patterns.

Press 's' to save a png image. Press 'e' to redraw and export a 4K png image. Note that drawing and physical simulation takes some time.

For interactive use, press 't' to tilt the board and 'c' to clear the board.

Written in p5.js with 2D physical simulation using Matter.js. Developed in and optimized for Chrome.

metadata.name: Plottable Era: (I) Primitive #104
metadata.description:
'Plottable Era: (I) Primitive' is the first generator in the "Era" generators series, highlighting different periods and civilizations. This first series "Primitive" shows the beginning of mankind with people exploring the mountains and traveling on the sea during sunset.

The digital version simulates ink effects and adds a subtle animation over the water. Each outcome is also physically plottable with pens: A SVG file can be exported (right-click save) to plot the piece physically. The plots are designed to be executed in A4 format on either fountain pens (on white paper) or gel pens (Black / Blue).

Thanks to the utility token decoupling, you can get a physical version: the digital NFT is the recipe to a plottable art piece, owning it confers the right to plot or request a physical plot from @greweb (https://greweb.me/plots/nft). @greweb would use fountain pens but other plotting artists are free to achieve it with their own materials and ship to collectors ‚Äì as long as NFT is owned at request time.

More details and Source code: https://github.com/gre/gre/tree/master/doodles/plottable-era-primitive

@greweb ‚Äì 2022 ‚Äì tech: WebGL + Rust + WASM ‚Äì CC BY-SA 4.0 https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/4.0/

reserve is set to previous 2022 physical plot collectors.

metadata.name: Ir/rational Beauty #129
metadata.description:
Released on the occasion of the Tribute to Herbert W. Franke. www.tribute-hwf.com

"Since the classical age of Greece, the golden ratio has been well known as the most balanced and therefore most aesthetically perfect proportion. In fact, it is supposedly often found in the fine arts and architecture and it is certainly important in geometry. But where is the proof that it is really the most beautiful proportion?

"The computer is proving to be a useful tool in exact art theory. Works of computer art are produced with the help of programs that describe the logic of the construction and its relevant measures. By varying the parameters you can vary the shapes of objects, and on the basis of the reaction of the public you can determine the best option. So it is possible to find valid rules to design works of art.

"A statistical evaluation would be interesting. Please email me with your results for the optimal proportion."

I found it heartwarming that in 2011, Herbert W. Franke wrote the above, accompanied with a simple functional program on a Wolfram Demonstration page (https://demonstrations.wolfram.com/IsTheGoldenRatioReallyTheMostBeautifulProportion/) titled 'Is the Golden Ratio Really the Most Beautiful Proportion?' and invited people to submit their findings to him.

The main idea behind this project is ratios, a variety of them, used in a variety of ways, such as how a rectangle is repeatedly subdivided, or how it influences the aspect ratio of the piece, or how the colors in a palette are selected. These are represented in various styles, some of which are inspired by the aesthetic of Herbert W. Franke's diverse artworks, and his openness to experimentation with new technologies, such as plotter drawings, screens, screenprints, or 2D and 3D digital renderings.

This project, while not designed to be a formal statistical evaluation, is but my fun, colorful, and humble response to your inquiry, dear Herbert.

---

25% of primary sales will be donated on-chain to the Foundation Herbert W. Franke, with the goal of raising 20,000 Euros so that ZKM Karlsruhe can digitize Herbert W. Franke‚Äôs 1,800 manuscripts and make them publicly available. Any money raised beyond this goal will be donated to the R√ºtgers Foundation which supports children and young adults in Africa so that they can get access to and work with technology.

---

Controls:
‚Ä¢ Double-click/tap or 'R' reassembles the piece (This automatically happens every minute)

Note: Some mints require WEBGL and/or may take several seconds to fully render.

Made in p5js
Created Oct 2022
Artist: @Yazid

metadata.name: Vortex #491
metadata.description: A collection of hundreds of thousands of points intertwining among each other like atoms to create a continuous real-time interactive vortex.

metadata.name: Through a Glass Darkly #6
metadata.description:
This generator uses 2D distortion to transform orderly geometric shapes into something fluid and seemingly irregular. The title refers to how during life, our perception of reality is incomplete, limited by time, perspective, and our senses.

----

In live view, double click or press "s" to save the image. URL parameters "width" and "height" are supported -- if you specify just width, the default aspect ratio of 17x11 is used. If you specify both, the resulting aspect ratio will result in some small composition changes.

metadata.name: A Less Traveled Path #154
metadata.description:
"I shall be telling this with a sigh
Somewhere ages and ages hence:
Two roads diverged in a wood, and I‚Äî
I took the one less traveled by,
And that has made all the difference."

- Robert Frost, The Road Not Taken



=========

Controls:
[1] set resolution to 1024x1024 (default)
[2] set resolution to 2048x2048 
[3] set resolution to 4096x4096
[0] set resolution to window size (might help on lower end computers)

[c] capture a screenshot at rendered resolution


Made with cables.gl, a node-based webgl environment
XALTED 2022

owner.name: C L A R C K =√ë

metadata.name: Part:Counterpart #30
metadata.description:
'Part:Counterpart' is an experiment in form, disintegration, and context. Each work is created within one of three modes, Part, Counterpart, or Part:Counterpart.

In experimenting, I've enjoyed taking a simple composition and breaking it down with various methods. This transforms the original composition into something new, but it also begins to lose what the original had to say. This isn't necessarily a bad thing, and I want to dive a little deeper and explore ideas as a sort of tangible substance. Already we're comparing ideas against their translations and evolutions, but what happens if we present them both within the context of the other?

Additionally, what if we present both of these ideas with echoes and tangents, discussion around the ideas and their practical applications instead of imagined? Sure, these aren't our idea, or even our translation, but they exist only because the originals do.

How does this change our opinion of the original? Is every idea destined to be picked apart and reimagined forever until it bears only a faint resemblance? Where is the line between our Counterpart and an echo?

This piece hopes to inspire contemplation on the nature of storytelling and artistic inspiration.

10% of ideas are encrypted to obscure the original Part.
Press ‚Äôs‚Äô to save a 3600x4500 png.
Press ‚Äòp‚Äô to save the original Part, pure and untouched.

owner.name: C L A R C K =√ë

metadata.name: Kaib≈ç #3
metadata.description:
What would happen if we took the natural forms that surround us and dissected them into composable shapes? 

Taking the organic world of Yashinoki, Kiab≈ç dissects organic forms into composable elements, then reforms them into precise geometric arrangements. These shapes give way to random, organic growth the closer we look at them. 


Controls in live mode:
- Press [s] to save a png

Made with code by AutoEclectus.
‚Ä®AutoEclectus is an artist specialising in code-based generative works.

owner.name: C L A R C K =√ë

metadata.name: Forgotten Memories #23
metadata.description:
Memories can be dark or they can be bright. Sometimes they are faint and pale, sometimes they are vivid and colorful. Sometimes they are hard to forget, sometimes they are easy to remember.

Memories are easily interrupted or even fractured, but they are also mostly always connected with other memories, whether they are related or not.

Forgotten Memories is what I consider to be my most ambitious study of color harmony yet. Each color represents a different category of memory, which are stored in our mind in layers of time. Their shapes differ in width and length depending on how weak/strong the memory was and how long it lasted.

Once a memory is forgotten, it may or may never be remembered again. But one thing that is not to be forgotten is that whether we choose to forget or remember, we are made of our memories.

* * *

Press S to save as PNG.
Press 1 to save with 1000px height.
Press 2 to save with 2000px height.

Made by: yenren / twitter.com/yenrenART
License: LICENSE.txt

metadata.name: DataWaves GEN #116
Magnolia Portrait #99
metadata.description:
Inspired by observation of the incessantly-rooted Pteridophyte and Magnolia, the cognominal series, ‚ÄúMagnolia‚Äù, portrays a manifestation of layers of constant streams crossing dynamically in a flow. Through years of growing in fluxed vapor, its knots and roots construct organized and rhythmic patterns within chaotic orders. From two-dimensional layouts to three-dimensional composition, ‚ÄúMagnolia‚Äù absorbs its fundamental image, and extend it even further ‚Äî creating the core of generative artwork.

Press "s" to download
